p.seg: LPART I. SUMMARY OF NEBRASKA COUNTIES. T n. FREIGHT RATES AND SHIPMENTS IN NEBRASKA ANNUAL BULLETIN NUMBER V. OF THE STATE BUREAU OF STATISTICS DECEMBER, 1906 BURRETT BUSH DEPUTY COMMISSIONER DON C. DESPAIN CHIEF CLERK

Office of the Bureau of Labor and Industrial Statistics. Lincoln, Nebraska, January 10, To His Excellency, HONORABLE GEORGE L. SHELDON, Governor of the State of Nebraska: El have the honor to present herewith, consideration, Annual Bulletin Number 1 i Bureau of Labor and Industrial v Very Respectfully Blkkett Bi sii f~)j*f)lJ fy ( OHl till N

PREFATORY NOTE This volume is the result of an effort to supply a Bulletin of reference relative to the resources and status of county in tin nd to giw9 a plain presentation of -IK>rtation charges in Nebraska which is a subject thor - oughly germane to the consideration of a community's cultural or industrial status. To answer the purix>se intend - ed the data herein has been compiled in as clear and 00 - possible. tPari I is devoted to an exhaustive analysis of ■ f of the state covering in detail such subjects as land rop production and values, shipment of various ■ificattona of land and the areas thereof, census opulation of towns, railway mileage, etc. T encompa nge of inquiries generally made con - ig the worth and advantages of a county. Part II deals with two subjects, relative one to the other, viz; frejght charges in the state and the shipment of products of the state. Freight charges are shown upon the principal articles of shipment and are enumerated by count - ving rates in force between Omaha and the principal shipping station of each county. Comparison is also made of average a the five states of Illinois, Iowa, raskaapd K. shipments of the products of tl >hown by counties, and in a general sum the tot uuent amounting to > It b the intention to present these sui anner, but as a plaii for r< and for the information of the public in <!■ al and the legislature in particular.
